content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nice puzzle, I think it is good for any mode ( shortest, fastest or reverse ). It can be written fast, and code can be relatively short, for reverse mode it is easy to see that in test cases there is arithmetic or geometric progression.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I like this clash. It is fun and a bit hard.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: It would be great of a shortest code style clash

Fine.
Easy with arithmetic sequences.
Might be disappointing with geometric sequences.
Do not propose the -1 1 -1 1 test, which is disapointing while -2 4 -8 16 is far less.
Interesting problem, but a little unpredictable.

This feels a bit arbitrary. Its not possible for clashers to know what you could include in your validators. I appreciate your statement in the constraints (which should probably be in the statement), but thats not going to help someone who is solving this as a reverse puzzle. You could put in the statement: "The sequence is always going to be either an arithmetic sequence (i.e. x(i+1) = X + x(i)) or a geometric sequence (i.e. x(i+1) = R*x(i))". But its too arbitrary when trying to solve this as a reverse puzzle. Let me know what your reaction to that is. (Also this is pretty similar to some other clashes that have been done before but since its up to the clasher to determine which type it is it seems unique enough.)

You shouldn't give the solution of a test case in it's own title, your instructions are already clear enough. 
Maybe "your program should find the next interger in the provided sequence.", would be even clearer ?
